titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Alexander Metcalf Fisher Papers
titlestmt.author: By Ève Bourbeau-Allard

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 22, 2019 at 05:59

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Alexander Metcalf Fisher papers consist of correspondence, scientific and personal writings, school notes, eulogies, and other material by or about the Yale College student (Class of 1813) and Yale professor. Drafts and calculations for articles on mathematics, physics, astronomy, and other subjects published between 1817 and 1822, as well as scripts for forty lectures in natural philosophy, illustrate Fisher's academic career in the context of contemporary scientific learning. Documenting the social, economic, religious, and emotional life of a young man living in New England during the Early Republic are extensive correspondence written by Fisher to his parents from 1809-1821, and eight personal and travel diaries. Correspondents also include other relatives, the Fisher family's pastor Nathanael Emmons, and Yale affiliates. Also contained in the collection is a portrait of Fisher engraved on copper by Simeon Smith Jocelyn.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: I. Correspondence, 1809-1825. II. Writings, 1803-1822. III. Personal and Family Papers, 1813-1898.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Alexander Metcalf Fisher was born in 1794 in Franklin, Massachusetts, to Caleb Fisher (1768-1862) and Sarah Cushing Fisher (1771-1835). Fisher studied at Yale College from 1809-1813, and at the Andover Theological Seminary in 1814, before returning to Yale in 1815 to serve as a tutor. He was later promoted to Adjunct Professor (1817) and Full Professor (1819) of Mathematics and Natural Philosophy. Before his premature death in the wreck of the ship Albion on 1822 April 22, Fisher was engaged to women's education advocate Catharine Esther Beecher (1800-1878).

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Alexander Metcalf Fisher Papers. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.
These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards. For more information, please refer to the Beinecke Manuscript Unit Processing Manual.
Former call numbers: MS Vault Fisher AM, MS Vault Section 5 Drawer 3, Z150.

The collection was first inventoried and verified in 1921-1922, and received partial arrangement and file description circa 1966 and 2015. Notes in typescript created circa 1966 were left in the folders with the material they describe. A collection file containing the original collection inventory can be found in Box 1.

Printed materials listed in the original inventory or legacy catalog records not found as of April 2018: Works of Virgil ("2 volumes bound together, London, 1794"), American Journal of Science and Arts (unspecified issues), and Catalogue of the members of the Connecticut Alpha of [the Phi Beta Kappa...] (1813).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Alexander Metcalf Fisher papers consist of correspondence, scientific and personal writings, school notes, eulogies, and other material by or about the Yale College student (Class of 1813) and Yale professor. Drafts and calculations for articles on mathematics, physics, astronomy, and other subjects published between 1817 and 1822, as well as scripts for forty lectures in natural philosophy, illustrate Fisher's academic career in the context of contemporary scientific learning. Documenting the social, economic, religious, and emotional life of a young man living in New England during the Early Republic are extensive correspondence written by Fisher to his parents from 1809-1821, and eight personal and travel diaries. Correspondents also include other relatives, the Fisher family's pastor Nathanael Emmons, and Yale affiliates. Also contained in the collection is a portrait of Fisher engraved on copper by Simeon Smith Jocelyn.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Thirteen printed items received with the collection, consisting largely of sermons, religious pamphlets, eulogies, and scientific texts, were removed for separate cataloging in April 2018. In the library's online catalog, those items are identified by the local note "From the Alexander Metcalf Fisher Papers", and the subject heading "Fisher, Alexander Metcalf, 1794-1822 -- Ownership". They can be found in the catalog by searching the phrase "Fisher, Alexander Metcalf" in the Special Collections Subject field.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Alexander Metcalf Fisher Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I. comprises correspondence to and from Fisher, family members, friends, and Yale affiliates. The bulk of the correspondence consists of letters sent by Fisher to his parents Caleb and Sarah over a period of thirteen years. Other correspondents include Fisher's siblings Nancy and Willard; Congregational minister Nathanael Emmons (1745-1840); theologian Edward Beecher (1803-1895), brother to Fisher's fiancée; President of Yale College Jeremiah Day (1773-1867); and Yale College Professor James Luce Kingsley (1778-1852). Most of the third-party correspondence documents the aftermath of Fisher's loss at sea in April 1822.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two letters regarding the settlement of Alexander Metcalf Fisher's estate, particularly the sale of his books.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Three letters written during Beecher's studies in Andover discussing Willard Fisher's religious feelings, and personal and family news.

did.unittitle: Emmons, Nathanael to Alexander Metcalf Fisher

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter of advice for Fisher's conduct at Yale.

did.unittitle: Fisher, Alexander Metcalf to Jeremiah Day
Fisher, Alexander Metcalf to Caleb and Sarah Fisher

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fifty-seven letters sent to his parents from New Haven, Connecticut, and from Andover, Massachussets, discussing his education, work as tutor and professor, health, financial needs, and family news.

did.unittitle: Fisher, Alexander Metcalf to Nancy Fisher

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Seven letters to his sister regarding her education, reading, and letter writing.

did.unittitle: Fisher, Alexander Metcalf to James Luce Kingsley

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a letter from aboard ship Albion, possibly Fisher's last extent correspondence.

did.unittitle: Fisher, Alexander Metcalf to Princeton University

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter draft regarding a position offer at Princeton.

did.unittitle: Fisher, Alexander Metcalf to unidentified editors, drafts
Fisher, Alexander Metcalf to unidentified correspondent
Kingsley, James Luce to Caleb Fisher

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two letters, including a transcription of a witness account of the Albion shipwreck.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into five subseries: Diaries, Scientific Articles, Lecture Scripts, Notes and Learning Exercises, and Other Writings. Files within subseries are arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II. contains holograph texts documenting Fisher's personal life, education, and academic work, in the form of diaries, article drafts, notebooks, commonplace books, lecture scripts, learning exercises, and school essays compiled during his primary schooling, collegiate education, and tenure as a Professor of Mathematics and Natural Philosophy at Yale College.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Groupings of unbound writings established by previous owners of the collection or library staff have been kept together during processing in 2018. Fragile volumes with deteriorated leather bindings are stored in separate boxes.

did.unittitle: "Brief heads of the plans begun & accomplished during 4 days past"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Short diary recorded in September 1815, followed by a twenty-four page commentary added in May 1817 on his mental health state during the recording of the original entry two years prior.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Formerly identified by owners of the collection or library staff as "Papers written during derangement".

did.unittitle: Travel diary from Litchfield, Connecticut, to Schenectady, New York
Travel diary through Rhode Island and Connecticut
Annotations to the article "The Compressibility of Water" by Jacob Perkins

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Published in the American Journal of Science and Arts 3, no.2 (May 1821).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Published in the American Journal of Science and Arts 1 (1819).

did.unittitle: Letters to the editors of The Microscope
Notebook containing reviews and other texts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bound manuscript containing solutions to mathematical problems published in contemporary journals, commentaries on the Gospels, solar eclipse calculations, notes titled "An improved method for solving some cases of maxima and minima" possibly relating to Fisher's published article on function extrema, and reviews of Jeremiah Day's A course of mathematics " (published in Analectic Magazine IX (June 1817)) and of Memoirs of the Connecticut Academy of Science .

did.unittitle: "Observations con[cerning] the management of algebraical problems"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Accompanied by a letter to Yale professor and editor of the American Journal of Science and Arts Benjamin Silliman, in Fisher's hand, forwarding a Diophantine problem solution by professor Theodore Strong of Hamilton College, and by various mathematical equations.

did.unittitle: "On maxima & minima of functions of two variable quantities"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Published in the American Journal of Science and Arts 5, no. 1 (1822).

did.unittitle: "On some recent improvements in the construction of the printing press"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Published in the American Journal of Science and Arts 3, no.2 (1821).

did.unittitle: "Remarks on Dr. Enfield's Institutes of Natural Philosophy"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Published in the American Journal of Science and Arts 3, no.1 (1821).

did.unittitle: Review of William Tudor's Letters on the Eastern States

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The lectures in natural philosophy comprise forty sequential volumes, each containing the script of a lecture on the recto, with citations on the verso. Topics covered include gravitation, motion, pneumatics, electricity, optics, and magnetism.

did.unittitle: Addresses to the Connecticut Academy [of Arts and Science] and to the Yale College junior class
Lectures in natural philosophy, no. I-XIII
Lectures in natural philosophy, no. XIV-XXVIII
Lectures in natural philosophy, no. XXIX-XL

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by title, when present, or by discipline.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Topical groupings may include notes from lectures, sermons, and publications; calculations; and short essays in response to question prompts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: First of two volumes covering 113 lectures attended by Fisher starting in 1812.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Second of two volumes covering 113 lectures attended by Fisher starting in 1812. The second volume also contains transcriptions of Timothy Dwight's farewell address to the senior class of Yale College (circa 1814) and of remarks by Dwight on William Paley's philosophy.

did.unittitle: "A collection of phrases, containing many of the most common idiomatic expressions in the Latin language"
"A commonplace book according to Locke's method"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes commentaries on theological works by William Paley and Charles Leslie.

did.unittitle: "Heads of directions for accurate and expressive singing"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Notes on sermons delivered by Mr. Fitch, Mr. Beecher, Mr. Taylor, and Dr. Worcester.

did.unittitle: "Miscellaneous hints on improvements in the arts"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Containing lecture notes, passages from theological and scholarly works, and other notes, including twenty pages titled "Public lectures on Christian theology by Dr. Woods" (presumably Leonard Woods (1774-1854), professor at Andover Theological Seminary), and "State of the philosophical apparatus of Yale College May 27, 1818", a seven page account of the scientific equipment procured by Yale College between 1769 and 1819 with their prices in pounds.

did.unittitle: "Remarks on tunes in the Lock Hospital"
"What are the fundamental rules of interpretation of Scriptures?", thesis for examination
By-laws of the Harmonic Society of New Haven County
"Journey to the moon or some of the planets", fiction piece

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III. holds manuscript and printed items relating to Fisher, his fiancé Catharine Esther Beecher, and his siblings Willard, Nancy, and Sally. Of note are clippings, eulogies, and poems in memory of Fisher, and records of his Yale College graduation, as well as a copper plate engraved with a portrait of Fisher by Simeon Smith Jocelyn.

did.unittitle: Article by D. Olmstead, "Anecdotes of Prof. Fisher", manuscript

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Published in The New Englander , no. IV (October 1843) as "Reminiscences of Alexander Metcalf Fisher".

did.unittitle: Clippings concerning the death of Alexander Metcalf Fisher
Clippings concerning the death of Catharine Esther Beecher
Eclipse projections by Willard Fisher, manuscript
Manuscript volume "Miscellaneous articles relating to the history, character & death of Prof. Fisher"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes an extract from a sermon by Nathanael Emmons preached on 1822 June 9, songs from Fisher's funerals, tombstone inscriptions, poems, and transcriptions of two letters recounting the shipwreck of the Albion.

did.unittitle: Minutes of two meetings [of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions, New Haven Chapter?]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manuscript copy of text published in the Christian Herald and Seaman's Magazine .

Poem by [?] Colton, "To the memory of Prof. Fisher", manuscript

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Engraving on copper plate by Simeon Smith Jocelyn, based on a painting by Samuel Finley Breese Morse. Caption "Prof. Alex. M. Fisher of Y. Coll. Lost in the Albion April 22nd 1822". 23 x 14 cm.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Previously contained manuscripts donated as part of the collection in 1921.

scopecontent.p: Late 18th-century or 19th-century dome-top wood trunk covered in decorative paper. 23 (height) x 44 (width) x 26 (depth) cm.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Manuscript note in ink on verso: "Papers written during derangement." The handbill may have previously been used as a wrapper for the diary and notes in Series II., Box 2, Folders 25-26.
